1""" 

2This module defines tensors with abstract index notation. 

3 

4The abstract index notation has been first formalized by Penrose. 

5 

6Tensor indices are formal objects, with a tensor type; there is no 

7notion of index range, it is only possible to assign the dimension, 

8used to trace the Kronecker delta; the dimension can be a Symbol. 

9 

10The Einstein summation convention is used. 

11The covariant indices are indicated with a minus sign in front of the index. 

12 

13For instance the tensor ``t = p(a)*A(b,c)*q(-c)`` has the index ``c`` 

14contracted. 

15 

16A tensor expression ``t`` can be called; called with its 

17indices in sorted order it is equal to itself: 

18in the above example ``t(a, b) == t``; 

19one can call ``t`` with different indices; ``t(c, d) == p(c)*A(d,a)*q(-a)``. 

20 

21The contracted indices are dummy indices, internally they have no name, 

22the indices being represented by a graph-like structure. 

23 

24Tensors are put in canonical form using ``canon_bp``, which uses 

25the Butler-Portugal algorithm for canonicalization using the monoterm 

26symmetries of the tensors. 

27 

28If there is a (anti)symmetric metric, the indices can be raised and 

29lowered when the tensor is put in canonical form. 

30""" 

31

57class _IndexStructure(CantSympify): 

58 """ 

59 This class handles the indices (free and dummy ones). It contains the 

60 algorithms to manage the dummy indices replacements and contractions of 

61 free indices under multiplications of tensor expressions, as well as stuff 

62 related to canonicalization sorting, getting the permutation of the 

63 expression and so on. It also includes tools to get the ``TensorIndex`` 

64 objects corresponding to the given index structure. 

65 """ 

66 

67 def __init__(self, free, dum, index_types, indices, canon_bp=False): 

68 self.free = free 

69 self.dum = dum 

70 self.index_types = index_types 

71 self.indices = indices 

72 self._ext_rank = len(self.free) + 2*len(self.dum) 

73 self.dum.sort(key=lambda x: x[0]) 

74 

75 @staticmethod 

76 def from_indices(*indices): 

77 """ 

78 Create a new ``_IndexStructure`` object from a list of ``indices`` 

79 

80 ``indices`` ``TensorIndex`` objects, the indices. Contractions are 

81 detected upon construction. 

82 

83 Examples 

84 ======== 

85 

86 >>> from sympy.tensor.tensor import TensorIndexType, tensor_indices, _IndexStructure 

87 >>> Lorentz = TensorIndexType('Lorentz', dummy_fmt='L') 

88 >>> m0, m1, m2, m3 = tensor_indices('m0,m1,m2,m3', Lorentz) 

89 >>> _IndexStructure.from_indices(m0, m1, -m1, m3) 

90 _IndexStructure([(m0, 0), (m3, 3)], [(1, 2)], [Lorentz, Lorentz, Lorentz, Lorentz]) 

91 

92 In case of many components the same indices have slightly different 

93 indexes: 

94 

95 >>> _IndexStructure.from_indices(m0, m1, -m1, m3) 

96 _IndexStructure([(m0, 0), (m3, 3)], [(1, 2)], [Lorentz, Lorentz, Lorentz, Lorentz]) 

97 """ 

98 free, dum = _IndexStructure._free_dum_from_indices(*indices) 

99 index_types = [i.tensor_index_type for i in indices] 

100 indices = _IndexStructure._replace_dummy_names(indices, free, dum) 

101 return _IndexStructure(free, dum, index_types, indices) 

102 

103 @staticmethod 

104 def from_components_free_dum(components, free, dum): 

105 index_types = [] 

106 for component in components: 

107 index_types.extend(component.index_types) 

108 indices = _IndexStructure.generate_indices_from_free_dum_index_types(free, dum, index_types) 

109 return _IndexStructure(free, dum, index_types, indices) 

110 

111 @staticmethod 

112 def _free_dum_from_indices(*indices): 

113 """ 

114 Convert ``indices`` into ``free``, ``dum`` for single component tensor 

115 

116 ``free`` list of tuples ``(index, pos, 0)``, 

117 where ``pos`` is the position of index in 

118 the list of indices formed by the component tensors 

119 

120 ``dum`` list of tuples ``(pos_contr, pos_cov, 0, 0)`` 

121 

122 Examples 

123 ======== 

124 

125 >>> from sympy.tensor.tensor import TensorIndexType, tensor_indices, \ 

126 _IndexStructure 

127 >>> Lorentz = TensorIndexType('Lorentz', dummy_fmt='L') 

128 >>> m0, m1, m2, m3 = tensor_indices('m0,m1,m2,m3', Lorentz) 

129 >>> _IndexStructure._free_dum_from_indices(m0, m1, -m1, m3) 

130 ([(m0, 0), (m3, 3)], [(1, 2)]) 

131 """ 

132 n = len(indices) 

133 if n == 1: 

134 return [(indices[0], 0)], [] 

135 

136 # find the positions of the free indices and of the dummy indices 

137 free = [True]*len(indices) 

138 index_dict = {} 

139 dum = [] 

140 for i, index in enumerate(indices): 

141 name = index._name 

142 typ = index.tensor_index_type 

143 contr = index._is_up 

144 if (name, typ) in index_dict: 

145 # found a pair of dummy indices 

146 is_contr, pos = index_dict[(name, typ)] 

147 # check consistency and update free 

148 if is_contr: 

149 if contr: 

150 raise ValueError('two equal contravariant indices in slots %d and %d' %(pos, i)) 

151 else: 

152 free[pos] = False 

153 free[i] = False 

154 else: 

155 if contr: 

156 free[pos] = False 

157 free[i] = False 

158 else: 

159 raise ValueError('two equal covariant indices in slots %d and %d' %(pos, i)) 

160 if contr: 

161 dum.append((i, pos)) 

162 else: 

163 dum.append((pos, i)) 

164 else: 

165 index_dict[(name, typ)] = index._is_up, i 

166 

167 free = [(index, i) for i, index in enumerate(indices) if free[i]] 

168 free.sort() 

169 return free, dum 

170 

171 def get_indices(self): 

172 """ 

173 Get a list of indices, creating new tensor indices to complete dummy indices. 

174 """ 

175 return self.indices[:] 

176 

177 @staticmethod 

178 def generate_indices_from_free_dum_index_types(free, dum, index_types): 

179 indices = [None]*(len(free)+2*len(dum)) 

180 for idx, pos in free: 

181 indices[pos] = idx 

182 

183 generate_dummy_name = _IndexStructure._get_generator_for_dummy_indices(free) 

184 for pos1, pos2 in dum: 

185 typ1 = index_types[pos1] 

186 indname = generate_dummy_name(typ1) 

187 indices[pos1] = TensorIndex(indname, typ1, True) 

188 indices[pos2] = TensorIndex(indname, typ1, False) 

189 

190 return _IndexStructure._replace_dummy_names(indices, free, dum) 

191 

192 @staticmethod 

193 def _get_generator_for_dummy_indices(free): 

194 cdt = defaultdict(int) 

195 # if the free indices have names with dummy_fmt, start with an 

196 # index higher than those for the dummy indices 

197 # to avoid name collisions 

198 for indx, ipos in free: 

199 if indx._name.split('_')[0] == indx.tensor_index_type.dummy_fmt[:-3]: 

200 cdt[indx.tensor_index_type] = max(cdt[indx.tensor_index_type], int(indx._name.split('_')[1]) + 1) 

201 

202 def dummy_fmt_gen(tensor_index_type): 

203 fmt = tensor_index_type.dummy_fmt 

204 nd = cdt[tensor_index_type] 

205 cdt[tensor_index_type] += 1 

206 return fmt % nd 

207 

208 return dummy_fmt_gen 

209 

210 @staticmethod 

211 def _replace_dummy_names(indices, free, dum): 

212 dum.sort(key=lambda x: x[0]) 

213 new_indices = [ind for ind in indices] 

214 assert len(indices) == len(free) + 2*len(dum) 

215 generate_dummy_name = _IndexStructure._get_generator_for_dummy_indices(free) 

216 for ipos1, ipos2 in dum: 

217 typ1 = new_indices[ipos1].tensor_index_type 

218 indname = generate_dummy_name(typ1) 

219 new_indices[ipos1] = TensorIndex(indname, typ1, True) 

220 new_indices[ipos2] = TensorIndex(indname, typ1, False) 

221 return new_indices 

222 

223 def get_free_indices(self): 

224 """ 

225 Get a list of free indices. 

226 """ 

227 # get sorted indices according to their position: 

228 free = sorted(self.free, key=lambda x: x[1]) 

229 return [i[0] for i in free]

231 def __str__(self): 

232 return "_IndexStructure({0}, {1}, {2})".format(self.free, self.dum, self.index_types)

234 def __repr__(self): 

235 return self.__str__()

237 def _get_sorted_free_indices_for_canon(self): 

238 sorted_free = self.free[:] 

239 sorted_free.sort(key=lambda x: x[0]) 

240 return sorted_free 

241 

242 def _get_sorted_dum_indices_for_canon(self): 

243 return sorted(self.dum, key=lambda x: x[0]) 

244 

245 def _get_lexicographically_sorted_index_types(self): 

246 permutation = self.indices_canon_args()[0] 

247 index_types = [None]*self._ext_rank 

248 for i, it in enumerate(self.index_types): 

249 index_types[permutation(i)] = it 

250 return index_types 

251 

252 def _get_lexicographically_sorted_indices(self): 

253 permutation = self.indices_canon_args()[0] 

254 indices = [None]*self._ext_rank 

255 for i, it in enumerate(self.indices): 

256 indices[permutation(i)] = it 

257 return indices

259 def perm2tensor(self, g, is_canon_bp=False): 

260 """ 

261 Returns a ``_IndexStructure`` instance corresponding to the permutation ``g`` 

262 

263 ``g`` permutation corresponding to the tensor in the representation 

264 used in canonicalization 

265 

266 ``is_canon_bp`` if True, then ``g`` is the permutation 

267 corresponding to the canonical form of the tensor 

268 """ 

269 sorted_free = [i[0] for i in self._get_sorted_free_indices_for_canon()] 

270 lex_index_types = self._get_lexicographically_sorted_index_types() 

271 lex_indices = self._get_lexicographically_sorted_indices() 

272 nfree = len(sorted_free) 

273 rank = self._ext_rank 

274 dum = [[None]*2 for i in range((rank - nfree)//2)] 

275 free = [] 

276 

277 index_types = [None]*rank 

278 indices = [None]*rank 

279 for i in range(rank): 

280 gi = g[i] 

281 index_types[i] = lex_index_types[gi] 

282 indices[i] = lex_indices[gi] 

283 if gi < nfree: 

284 ind = sorted_free[gi] 

285 assert index_types[i] == sorted_free[gi].tensor_index_type 

286 free.append((ind, i)) 

287 else: 

288 j = gi - nfree 

289 idum, cov = divmod(j, 2) 

290 if cov: 

291 dum[idum][1] = i 

292 else: 

293 dum[idum][0] = i 

294 dum = [tuple(x) for x in dum] 

295 

296 return _IndexStructure(free, dum, index_types, indices) 

297 

298 def indices_canon_args(self): 

299 """ 

300 Returns ``(g, dummies, msym, v)``, the entries of ``canonicalize`` 

301 

302 see ``canonicalize`` in ``tensor_can.py`` 

303 """ 

304 # to be called after sorted_components 

305 from sympy.combinatorics.permutations import _af_new 

306 n = self._ext_rank 

307 g = [None]*n + [n, n+1] 

308 

309 # ordered indices: first the free indices, ordered by types 

310 # then the dummy indices, ordered by types and contravariant before 

311 # covariant 

312 # g[position in tensor] = position in ordered indices 

313 for i, (indx, ipos) in enumerate(self._get_sorted_free_indices_for_canon()): 

314 g[ipos] = i 

315 pos = len(self.free) 

316 j = len(self.free) 

317 dummies = [] 

318 prev = None 

319 a = [] 

320 msym = [] 

321 for ipos1, ipos2 in self._get_sorted_dum_indices_for_canon(): 

322 g[ipos1] = j 

323 g[ipos2] = j + 1 

324 j += 2 

325 typ = self.index_types[ipos1] 

326 if typ != prev: 

327 if a: 

328 dummies.append(a) 

329 a = [pos, pos + 1] 

330 prev = typ 

331 msym.append(typ.metric_antisym) 

332 else: 

333 a.extend([pos, pos + 1]) 

334 pos += 2 

335 if a: 

336 dummies.append(a) 

337 

338 return _af_new(g), dummies, msym 

339 

340 

341def components_canon_args(components): 

342 numtyp = [] 

343 prev = None 

344 for t in components: 

345 if t == prev: 

346 numtyp[-1][1] += 1 

347 else: 

348 prev = t 

349 numtyp.append([prev, 1]) 

350 v = [] 

351 for h, n in numtyp: 

352 if h._comm == 0 or h._comm == 1: 

353 comm = h._comm 

354 else: 

355 comm = TensorManager.get_comm(h._comm, h._comm) 

356 v.append((h._symmetry.base, h._symmetry.generators, n, comm)) 

357 return v

360class _TensorDataLazyEvaluator(CantSympify): 

361 """ 

362 EXPERIMENTAL: do not rely on this class, it may change without deprecation 

363 warnings in future versions of SymPy. 

364 

365 This object contains the logic to associate components data to a tensor 

366 expression. Components data are set via the ``.data`` property of tensor 

367 expressions, is stored inside this class as a mapping between the tensor 

368 expression and the ``ndarray``. 

369 

370 Computations are executed lazily: whereas the tensor expressions can have 

371 contractions, tensor products, and additions, components data are not 

372 computed until they are accessed by reading the ``.data`` property 

373 associated to the tensor expression. 

374 """ 

375 _substitutions_dict = dict() 

376 _substitutions_dict_tensmul = dict() 

377 

378 def __getitem__(self, key): 

379 dat = self._get(key) 

380 if dat is None: 

381 return None 

382 

383 from .array import NDimArray 

384 if not isinstance(dat, NDimArray): 

385 return dat 

386 

387 if dat.rank() == 0: 

388 return dat[()] 

389 elif dat.rank() == 1 and len(dat) == 1: 

390 return dat[0] 

391 return dat 

392 

393 def _get(self, key): 

394 """ 

395 Retrieve ``data`` associated with ``key``. 

396 

397 This algorithm looks into ``self._substitutions_dict`` for all 

398 ``TensorHead`` in the ``TensExpr`` (or just ``TensorHead`` if key is a 

399 TensorHead instance). It reconstructs the components data that the 

400 tensor expression should have by performing on components data the 

401 operations that correspond to the abstract tensor operations applied. 

402 

403 Metric tensor is handled in a different manner: it is pre-computed in 

404 ``self._substitutions_dict_tensmul``. 

405 """ 

406 if key in self._substitutions_dict: 

407 return self._substitutions_dict[key] 

408 

409 if isinstance(key, TensorHead): 

410 return None 

411 

412 if isinstance(key, Tensor): 

413 # special case to handle metrics. Metric tensors cannot be 

414 # constructed through contraction by the metric, their 

415 # components show if they are a matrix or its inverse. 

416 signature = tuple([i.is_up for i in key.get_indices()]) 

417 srch = (key.component,) + signature 

418 if srch in self._substitutions_dict_tensmul: 

419 return self._substitutions_dict_tensmul[srch] 

420 array_list = [self.data_from_tensor(key)] 

421 return self.data_contract_dum(array_list, key.dum, key.ext_rank) 

422 

423 if isinstance(key, TensMul): 

424 tensmul_args = key.args 

425 if len(tensmul_args) == 1 and len(tensmul_args[0].components) == 1: 

426 # special case to handle metrics. Metric tensors cannot be 

427 # constructed through contraction by the metric, their 

428 # components show if they are a matrix or its inverse. 

429 signature = tuple([i.is_up for i in tensmul_args[0].get_indices()]) 

430 srch = (tensmul_args[0].components[0],) + signature 

431 if srch in self._substitutions_dict_tensmul: 

432 return self._substitutions_dict_tensmul[srch] 

433 #data_list = [self.data_from_tensor(i) for i in tensmul_args if isinstance(i, TensExpr)] 

434 data_list = [self.data_from_tensor(i) if isinstance(i, Tensor) else i.data for i in tensmul_args if isinstance(i, TensExpr)] 

435 coeff = prod([i for i in tensmul_args if not isinstance(i, TensExpr)]) 

436 if all([i is None for i in data_list]): 

437 return None 

438 if any([i is None for i in data_list]): 

439 raise ValueError("Mixing tensors with associated components "\ 

440 "data with tensors without components data") 

441 data_result = self.data_contract_dum(data_list, key.dum, key.ext_rank) 

442 return coeff*data_result 

443 

444 if isinstance(key, TensAdd): 

445 data_list = [] 

446 free_args_list = [] 

447 for arg in key.args: 

448 if isinstance(arg, TensExpr): 

449 data_list.append(arg.data) 

450 free_args_list.append([x[0] for x in arg.free]) 

451 else: 

452 data_list.append(arg) 

453 free_args_list.append([]) 

454 if all([i is None for i in data_list]): 

455 return None 

456 if any([i is None for i in data_list]): 

457 raise ValueError("Mixing tensors with associated components "\ 

458 "data with tensors without components data") 

459 

460 sum_list = [] 

461 from .array import permutedims 

462 for data, free_args in zip(data_list, free_args_list): 

463 if len(free_args) < 2: 

464 sum_list.append(data) 

465 else: 

466 free_args_pos = {y: x for x, y in enumerate(free_args)} 

467 axes = [free_args_pos[arg] for arg in key.free_args] 

468 sum_list.append(permutedims(data, axes)) 

469 return reduce(lambda x, y: x+y, sum_list) 

470 

471 return None 

472 

473 @staticmethod 

474 def data_contract_dum(ndarray_list, dum, ext_rank): 

475 from .array import tensorproduct, tensorcontraction, MutableDenseNDimArray 

476 arrays = list(map(MutableDenseNDimArray, ndarray_list)) 

477 prodarr = tensorproduct(*arrays) 

478 return tensorcontraction(prodarr, *dum)

480 def data_tensorhead_from_tensmul(self, data, tensmul, tensorhead): 

481 """ 

482 This method is used when assigning components data to a ``TensMul`` 

483 object, it converts components data to a fully contravariant ndarray, 

484 which is then stored according to the ``TensorHead`` key. 

485 """ 

486 if data is None: 

487 return None 

488 

489 return self._correct_signature_from_indices( 

490 data, 

491 tensmul.get_indices(), 

492 tensmul.free, 

493 tensmul.dum, 

494 True) 

495 

496 def data_from_tensor(self, tensor): 

497 """ 

498 This method corrects the components data to the right signature 

499 (covariant/contravariant) using the metric associated with each 

500 ``TensorIndexType``. 

501 """ 

502 tensorhead = tensor.component 

503 

504 if tensorhead.data is None: 

505 return None 

506 

507 return self._correct_signature_from_indices( 

508 tensorhead.data, 

509 tensor.get_indices(), 

510 tensor.free, 

511 tensor.dum) 

512 

513 def _assign_data_to_tensor_expr(self, key, data): 

514 if isinstance(key, TensAdd): 

515 raise ValueError('cannot assign data to TensAdd') 

516 # here it is assumed that `key` is a `TensMul` instance. 

517 if len(key.components) != 1: 

518 raise ValueError('cannot assign data to TensMul with multiple components') 

519 tensorhead = key.components[0] 

520 newdata = self.data_tensorhead_from_tensmul(data, key, tensorhead) 

521 return tensorhead, newdata 

522 

523 def _check_permutations_on_data(self, tens, data): 

524 from .array import permutedims 

525 

526 if isinstance(tens, TensorHead): 

527 rank = tens.rank 

528 generators = tens.symmetry.generators 

529 elif isinstance(tens, Tensor): 

530 rank = tens.rank 

531 generators = tens.components[0].symmetry.generators 

532 elif isinstance(tens, TensorIndexType): 

533 rank = tens.metric.rank 

534 generators = tens.metric.symmetry.generators 

535 

536 # Every generator is a permutation, check that by permuting the array 

537 # by that permutation, the array will be the same, except for a 

538 # possible sign change if the permutation admits it. 

539 for gener in generators: 

540 sign_change = +1 if (gener(rank) == rank) else -1 

541 data_swapped = data 

542 last_data = data 

543 permute_axes = list(map(gener, list(range(rank)))) 

544 # the order of a permutation is the number of times to get the 

545 # identity by applying that permutation. 

546 for i in range(gener.order()-1): 

547 data_swapped = permutedims(data_swapped, permute_axes) 

548 # if any value in the difference array is non-zero, raise an error: 

549 if any(last_data - sign_change*data_swapped): 

550 raise ValueError("Component data symmetry structure error") 

551 last_data = data_swapped 

552 

553 def __setitem__(self, key, value): 

554 """ 

555 Set the components data of a tensor object/expression. 

556 

557 Components data are transformed to the all-contravariant form and stored 

558 with the corresponding ``TensorHead`` object. If a ``TensorHead`` object 

559 cannot be uniquely identified, it will raise an error. 

560 """ 

561 data = _TensorDataLazyEvaluator.parse_data(value) 

562 self._check_permutations_on_data(key, data) 

563 

564 # TensorHead and TensorIndexType can be assigned data directly, while 

565 # TensMul must first convert data to a fully contravariant form, and 

566 # assign it to its corresponding TensorHead single component. 

567 if not isinstance(key, (TensorHead, TensorIndexType)): 

568 key, data = self._assign_data_to_tensor_expr(key, data) 

569 

570 if isinstance(key, TensorHead): 

571 for dim, indextype in zip(data.shape, key.index_types): 

572 if indextype.data is None: 

573 raise ValueError("index type {} has no components data"\ 

574 " associated (needed to raise/lower index)".format(indextype)) 

575 if indextype.dim is None: 

576 continue 

577 if dim != indextype.dim: 

578 raise ValueError("wrong dimension of ndarray") 

579 self._substitutions_dict[key] = data 

580 

581 def __delitem__(self, key): 

582 del self._substitutions_dict[key] 

583 

584 def __contains__(self, key): 

585 return key in self._substitutions_dict

587 def add_metric_data(self, metric, data): 

588 """ 

589 Assign data to the ``metric`` tensor. The metric tensor behaves in an 

590 anomalous way when raising and lowering indices. 

591 

592 A fully covariant metric is the inverse transpose of the fully 

593 contravariant metric (it is meant matrix inverse). If the metric is 

594 symmetric, the transpose is not necessary and mixed 

595 covariant/contravariant metrics are Kronecker deltas. 

596 """ 

597 # hard assignment, data should not be added to `TensorHead` for metric: 

598 # the problem with `TensorHead` is that the metric is anomalous, i.e. 

599 # raising and lowering the index means considering the metric or its 

600 # inverse, this is not the case for other tensors. 

601 self._substitutions_dict_tensmul[metric, True, True] = data 

602 inverse_transpose = self.inverse_transpose_matrix(data) 

603 # in symmetric spaces, the traspose is the same as the original matrix, 

604 # the full covariant metric tensor is the inverse transpose, so this 

605 # code will be able to handle non-symmetric metrics. 

606 self._substitutions_dict_tensmul[metric, False, False] = inverse_transpose 

607 # now mixed cases, these are identical to the unit matrix if the metric 

608 # is symmetric. 

609 m = data.tomatrix() 

610 invt = inverse_transpose.tomatrix() 

611 self._substitutions_dict_tensmul[metric, True, False] = m * invt 

612 self._substitutions_dict_tensmul[metric, False, True] = invt * m 

613 

614 @staticmethod 

615 def _flip_index_by_metric(data, metric, pos): 

616 from .array import tensorproduct, tensorcontraction 

617 

618 mdim = metric.rank() 

619 ddim = data.rank() 

620 

621 if pos == 0: 

622 data = tensorcontraction( 

623 tensorproduct( 

624 metric, 

625 data 

626 ), 

627 (1, mdim+pos) 

628 ) 

629 else: 

630 data = tensorcontraction( 

631 tensorproduct( 

632 data, 

633 metric 

634 ), 

635 (pos, ddim) 

636 ) 

637 return data 

638 

639 @staticmethod 

640 def inverse_matrix(ndarray): 

641 m = ndarray.tomatrix().inv() 

642 return _TensorDataLazyEvaluator.parse_data(m) 

643 

644 @staticmethod 

645 def inverse_transpose_matrix(ndarray): 

646 m = ndarray.tomatrix().inv().T 

647 return _TensorDataLazyEvaluator.parse_data(m) 

648 

649 @staticmethod 

650 def _correct_signature_from_indices(data, indices, free, dum, inverse=False): 

651 """ 

652 Utility function to correct the values inside the components data 

653 ndarray according to whether indices are covariant or contravariant. 

654 

655 It uses the metric matrix to lower values of covariant indices. 

656 """ 

657 # change the ndarray values according covariantness/contravariantness of the indices 

658 # use the metric 

659 for i, indx in enumerate(indices): 

660 if not indx.is_up and not inverse: 

661 data = _TensorDataLazyEvaluator._flip_index_by_metric(data, indx.tensor_index_type.data, i) 

662 elif not indx.is_up and inverse: 

663 data = _TensorDataLazyEvaluator._flip_index_by_metric( 

664 data, 

665 _TensorDataLazyEvaluator.inverse_matrix(indx.tensor_index_type.data), 

666 i 

667 ) 

668 return data 

669 

670 @staticmethod 

671 def _sort_data_axes(old, new): 

672 from .array import permutedims 

673 

674 new_data = old.data.copy() 

675 

676 old_free = [i[0] for i in old.free] 

677 new_free = [i[0] for i in new.free] 

678 

679 for i in range(len(new_free)): 

680 for j in range(i, len(old_free)): 

681 if old_free[j] == new_free[i]: 

682 old_free[i], old_free[j] = old_free[j], old_free[i] 

683 new_data = permutedims(new_data, (i, j)) 

684 break 

685 return new_data 

686 

687 @staticmethod 

688 def add_rearrange_tensmul_parts(new_tensmul, old_tensmul): 

689 def sorted_compo(): 

690 return _TensorDataLazyEvaluator._sort_data_axes(old_tensmul, new_tensmul) 

691 

692 _TensorDataLazyEvaluator._substitutions_dict[new_tensmul] = sorted_compo() 

693 

694 @staticmethod 

695 def parse_data(data): 

696 """ 

697 Transform ``data`` to array. The parameter ``data`` may 

698 contain data in various formats, e.g. nested lists, sympy ``Matrix``, 

699 and so on. 

700 

701 Examples 

702 ======== 

703 

704 >>> from sympy.tensor.tensor import _TensorDataLazyEvaluator 

705 >>> _TensorDataLazyEvaluator.parse_data([1, 3, -6, 12]) 

706 [1, 3, -6, 12] 

707 

708 >>> _TensorDataLazyEvaluator.parse_data([[1, 2], [4, 7]]) 

709 [[1, 2], [4, 7]] 

710 """ 

711 from .array import MutableDenseNDimArray 

712 

713 if not isinstance(data, MutableDenseNDimArray): 

714 if len(data) == 2 and hasattr(data[0], '__call__'): 

715 data = MutableDenseNDimArray(data[0], data[1]) 

716 else: 

717 data = MutableDenseNDimArray(data) 

718 return data 

719 

720_tensor_data_substitution_dict = _TensorDataLazyEvaluator() 

721 

722 

723class _TensorManager(object): 

724 """ 

725 Class to manage tensor properties. 

726 

727 Notes 

728 ===== 

729 

730 Tensors belong to tensor commutation groups; each group has a label 

731 ``comm``; there are predefined labels: 

732 

733 ``0`` tensors commuting with any other tensor 

734 

735 ``1`` tensors anticommuting among themselves 

736 

737 ``2`` tensors not commuting, apart with those with ``comm=0`` 

738 

739 Other groups can be defined using ``set_comm``; tensors in those 

740 groups commute with those with ``comm=0``; by default they 

741 do not commute with any other group. 

742 """ 

743 def __init__(self): 

744 self._comm_init() 

745 

746 def _comm_init(self): 

747 self._comm = [{} for i in range(3)] 

748 for i in range(3): 

749 self._comm[0][i] = 0 

750 self._comm[i][0] = 0 

751 self._comm[1][1] = 1 

752 self._comm[2][1] = None 

753 self._comm[1][2] = None 

754 self._comm_symbols2i = {0:0, 1:1, 2:2} 

755 self._comm_i2symbol = {0:0, 1:1, 2:2} 

756 

757 @property 

758 def comm(self): 

759 return self._comm 

760 

761 def comm_symbols2i(self, i): 

762 """ 

763 get the commutation group number corresponding to ``i`` 

764 

765 ``i`` can be a symbol or a number or a string 

766 

767 If ``i`` is not already defined its commutation group number 

768 is set. 

769 """ 

770 if i not in self._comm_symbols2i: 

771 n = len(self._comm) 

772 self._comm.append({}) 

773 self._comm[n][0] = 0 

774 self._comm[0][n] = 0 

775 self._comm_symbols2i[i] = n 

776 self._comm_i2symbol[n] = i 

777 return n 

778 return self._comm_symbols2i[i] 

779 

780 def comm_i2symbol(self, i): 

781 """ 

782 Returns the symbol corresponding to the commutation group number. 

783 """ 

784 return self._comm_i2symbol[i] 

785 

786 def set_comm(self, i, j, c): 

787 """ 

788 set the commutation parameter ``c`` for commutation groups ``i, j`` 

789 

790 Parameters 

791 ========== 

792 

793 i, j : symbols representing commutation groups 

794 

795 c : group commutation number 

796 

797 Notes 

798 ===== 

799 

800 ``i, j`` can be symbols, strings or numbers, 

801 apart from ``0, 1`` and ``2`` which are reserved respectively 

802 for commuting, anticommuting tensors and tensors not commuting 

803 with any other group apart with the commuting tensors. 

804 For the remaining cases, use this method to set the commutation rules; 

805 by default ``c=None``. 

806 

807 The group commutation number ``c`` is assigned in correspondence 

808 to the group commutation symbols; it can be 

809 

810 0 commuting 

811 

812 1 anticommuting 

813 

814 None no commutation property 

815 

816 Examples 

817 ======== 

818 

819 ``G`` and ``GH`` do not commute with themselves and commute with 

820 each other; A is commuting. 

821 

822 >>> from sympy.tensor.tensor import TensorIndexType, tensor_indices, tensorhead, TensorManager 

823 >>> Lorentz = TensorIndexType('Lorentz') 

824 >>> i0,i1,i2,i3,i4 = tensor_indices('i0:5', Lorentz) 

825 >>> A = tensorhead('A', [Lorentz], [[1]]) 

826 >>> G = tensorhead('G', [Lorentz], [[1]], 'Gcomm') 

827 >>> GH = tensorhead('GH', [Lorentz], [[1]], 'GHcomm') 

828 >>> TensorManager.set_comm('Gcomm', 'GHcomm', 0) 

829 >>> (GH(i1)*G(i0)).canon_bp() 

830 G(i0)*GH(i1) 

831 >>> (G(i1)*G(i0)).canon_bp() 

832 G(i1)*G(i0) 

833 >>> (G(i1)*A(i0)).canon_bp() 

834 A(i0)*G(i1) 

835 """ 

836 if c not in (0, 1, None): 

837 raise ValueError('`c` can assume only the values 0, 1 or None') 

838 

839 if i not in self._comm_symbols2i: 

840 n = len(self._comm) 

841 self._comm.append({}) 

842 self._comm[n][0] = 0 

843 self._comm[0][n] = 0 

844 self._comm_symbols2i[i] = n 

845 self._comm_i2symbol[n] = i 

846 if j not in self._comm_symbols2i: 

847 n = len(self._comm) 

848 self._comm.append({}) 

849 self._comm[0][n] = 0 

850 self._comm[n][0] = 0 

851 self._comm_symbols2i[j] = n 

852 self._comm_i2symbol[n] = j 

853 ni = self._comm_symbols2i[i] 

854 nj = self._comm_symbols2i[j] 

855 self._comm[ni][nj] = c 

856 self._comm[nj][ni] = c 

857 

858 def set_comms(self, *args): 

859 """ 

860 set the commutation group numbers ``c`` for symbols ``i, j`` 

861 

862 Parameters 

863 ========== 

864 

865 args : sequence of ``(i, j, c)`` 

866 """ 

867 for i, j, c in args: 

868 self.set_comm(i, j, c) 

869 

870 def get_comm(self, i, j): 

871 """ 

872 Return the commutation parameter for commutation group numbers ``i, j`` 

873 

874 see ``_TensorManager.set_comm`` 

875 """ 

876 return self._comm[i].get(j, 0 if i == 0 or j == 0 else None) 

877 

878 def clear(self): 

879 """ 

880 Clear the TensorManager. 

881 """ 

882 self._comm_init() 

883 

884 

885TensorManager = _TensorManager() 

886 

887 

888class TensorIndexType(Basic): 

889 """ 

890 A TensorIndexType is characterized by its name and its metric. 

891 

892 Parameters 

893 ========== 

894 

895 name : name of the tensor type 

896 

897 metric : metric symmetry or metric object or ``None`` 

898 

899 

900 dim : dimension, it can be a symbol or an integer or ``None`` 

901 

902 eps_dim : dimension of the epsilon tensor 

903 

904 dummy_fmt : name of the head of dummy indices 

905 

906 Attributes 

907 ========== 

908 

909 ``name`` 

910 ``metric_name`` : it is 'metric' or metric.name 

911 ``metric_antisym`` 

912 ``metric`` : the metric tensor 

913 ``delta`` : ``Kronecker delta`` 

914 ``epsilon`` : the ``Levi-Civita epsilon`` tensor 

915 ``dim`` 

916 ``eps_dim`` 

917 ``dummy_fmt`` 

918 ``data`` : a property to add ``ndarray`` values, to work in a specified basis. 

919 

920 Notes 

921 ===== 

922 

923 The ``metric`` parameter can be: 

924 ``metric = False`` symmetric metric (in Riemannian geometry) 

925 

926 ``metric = True`` antisymmetric metric (for spinor calculus) 

927 

928 ``metric = None`` there is no metric 

929 

930 ``metric`` can be an object having ``name`` and ``antisym`` attributes. 

931 

932 

933 If there is a metric the metric is used to raise and lower indices. 

934 

935 In the case of antisymmetric metric, the following raising and 

936 lowering conventions will be adopted: 

937 

938 ``psi(a) = g(a, b)*psi(-b); chi(-a) = chi(b)*g(-b, -a)`` 

939 

940 ``g(-a, b) = delta(-a, b); g(b, -a) = -delta(a, -b)`` 

941 

942 where ``delta(-a, b) = delta(b, -a)`` is the ``Kronecker delta`` 

943 (see ``TensorIndex`` for the conventions on indices). 

944 

945 If there is no metric it is not possible to raise or lower indices; 

946 e.g. the index of the defining representation of ``SU(N)`` 

947 is 'covariant' and the conjugate representation is 

948 'contravariant'; for ``N > 2`` they are linearly independent. 

949 

950 ``eps_dim`` is by default equal to ``dim``, if the latter is an integer; 

951 else it can be assigned (for use in naive dimensional regularization); 

952 if ``eps_dim`` is not an integer ``epsilon`` is ``None``. 

953 

954 Examples 

955 ======== 

956 

957 >>> from sympy.tensor.tensor import TensorIndexType 

958 >>> Lorentz = TensorIndexType('Lorentz', dummy_fmt='L') 

959 >>> Lorentz.metric 

960 metric(Lorentz,Lorentz) 

961 """ 

962 

963 def __new__(cls, name, metric=False, dim=None, eps_dim=None, 

964 dummy_fmt=None): 

965 

966 if isinstance(name, string_types): 

967 name = Symbol(name) 

968 obj = Basic.__new__(cls, name, S.One if metric else S.Zero) 

969 obj._name = str(name) 

970 if not dummy_fmt: 

971 obj._dummy_fmt = '%s_%%d' % obj.name 

972 else: 

973 obj._dummy_fmt = '%s_%%d' % dummy_fmt 

974 if metric is None: 

975 obj.metric_antisym = None 

976 obj.metric = None 

977 else: 

978 if metric in (True, False, 0, 1): 

979 metric_name = 'metric' 

980 obj.metric_antisym = metric 

981 else: 

982 metric_name = metric.name 

983 obj.metric_antisym = metric.antisym 

984 sym2 = TensorSymmetry(get_symmetric_group_sgs(2, obj.metric_antisym)) 

985 S2 = TensorType([obj]*2, sym2) 

986 obj.metric = S2(metric_name) 

987 

988 obj._dim = dim 

989 obj._delta = obj.get_kronecker_delta() 

990 obj._eps_dim = eps_dim if eps_dim else dim 

991 obj._epsilon = obj.get_epsilon() 

992 obj._autogenerated = [] 

993 return obj 

994 

995 @property 

996 @deprecated(useinstead="TensorIndex", issue=12857, deprecated_since_version="1.1") 

997 def auto_right(self): 

998 if not hasattr(self, '_auto_right'): 

999 self._auto_right = TensorIndex("auto_right", self) 

1000 return self._auto_right 

1001 

1002 @property 

1003 @deprecated(useinstead="TensorIndex", issue=12857, deprecated_since_version="1.1") 

1004 def auto_left(self): 

1005 if not hasattr(self, '_auto_left'): 

1006 self._auto_left = TensorIndex("auto_left", self) 

1007 return self._auto_left 

1008 

1009 @property 

1010 @deprecated(useinstead="TensorIndex", issue=12857, deprecated_since_version="1.1") 

1011 def auto_index(self): 

1012 if not hasattr(self, '_auto_index'): 

1013 self._auto_index = TensorIndex("auto_index", self) 

1014 return self._auto_index 

1015 

1016 @property 

1017 def data(self): 

1018 deprecate_data() 

1019 return _tensor_data_substitution_dict[self] 

1020 

1021 @data.setter 

1022 def data(self, data): 

1023 deprecate_data() 

1024 # This assignment is a bit controversial, should metric components be assigned 

1025 # to the metric only or also to the TensorIndexType object? The advantage here 

1026 # is the ability to assign a 1D array and transform it to a 2D diagonal array. 

1027 from .array import MutableDenseNDimArray 

1028 

1029 data = _TensorDataLazyEvaluator.parse_data(data) 

1030 if data.rank() > 2: 

1031 raise ValueError("data have to be of rank 1 (diagonal metric) or 2.") 

1032 if data.rank() == 1: 

1033 if self.dim is not None: 

1034 nda_dim = data.shape[0] 

1035 if nda_dim != self.dim: 

1036 raise ValueError("Dimension mismatch") 

1037 

1038 dim = data.shape[0] 

1039 newndarray = MutableDenseNDimArray.zeros(dim, dim) 

1040 for i, val in enumerate(data): 

1041 newndarray[i, i] = val 

1042 data = newndarray 

1043 dim1, dim2 = data.shape 

1044 if dim1 != dim2: 

1045 raise ValueError("Non-square matrix tensor.") 

1046 if self.dim is not None: 

1047 if self.dim != dim1: 

1048 raise ValueError("Dimension mismatch") 

1049 _tensor_data_substitution_dict[self] = data 

1050 _tensor_data_substitution_dict.add_metric_data(self.metric, data) 

1051 delta = self.get_kronecker_delta() 

1052 i1 = TensorIndex('i1', self) 

1053 i2 = TensorIndex('i2', self) 

1054 delta(i1, -i2).data = _TensorDataLazyEvaluator.parse_data(eye(dim1)) 

1055 

1056 @data.deleter 

1057 def data(self): 

1058 deprecate_data() 

1059 if self in _tensor_data_substitution_dict: 

1060 del _tensor_data_substitution_dict[self] 

1061 if self.metric in _tensor_data_substitution_dict: 

1062 del _tensor_data_substitution_dict[self.metric] 

1063 

1064 def _get_matrix_fmt(self, number): 

1065 return ("m" + self.dummy_fmt) % (number) 

1066 

1067 @property 

1068 def name(self): 

1069 return self._name 

1070 

1071 @property 

1072 def dim(self): 

1073 return self._dim 

1074 

1075 @property 

1076 def delta(self): 

1077 return self._delta 

1078 

1079 @property 

1080 def eps_dim(self): 

1081 return self._eps_dim 

1082 

1083 @property 

1084 def epsilon(self): 

1085 return self._epsilon 

1086 

1087 @property 

1088 def dummy_fmt(self): 

1089 return self._dummy_fmt 

1090 

1091 def get_kronecker_delta(self): 

1092 sym2 = TensorSymmetry(get_symmetric_group_sgs(2)) 

1093 S2 = TensorType([self]*2, sym2) 

1094 delta = S2('KD') 

1095 return delta 

1096 

1097 def get_epsilon(self): 

1098 if not isinstance(self._eps_dim, (SYMPY_INTS, Integer)): 

1099 return None 

1100 sym = TensorSymmetry(get_symmetric_group_sgs(self._eps_dim, 1)) 

1101 Sdim = TensorType([self]*self._eps_dim, sym) 

1102 epsilon = Sdim('Eps') 

1103 return epsilon 

1104 

1105 def __lt__(self, other): 

1106 return self.name < other.name 

1107 

1108 def __str__(self): 

1109 return self.name 

1110 

1111 __repr__ = __str__ 

1112 

1113 def _components_data_full_destroy(self): 

1114 """ 

1115 EXPERIMENTAL: do not rely on this API method. 

1116 

1117 This destroys components data associated to the ``TensorIndexType``, if 

1118 any, specifically: 

1119 

1120 * metric tensor data 

1121 * Kronecker tensor data 

1122 """ 

1123 if self in _tensor_data_substitution_dict: 

1124 del _tensor_data_substitution_dict[self] 

1125 

1126 def delete_tensmul_data(key): 

1127 if key in _tensor_data_substitution_dict._substitutions_dict_tensmul: 

1128 del _tensor_data_substitution_dict._substitutions_dict_tensmul[key] 

1129 

1130 # delete metric data: 

1131 delete_tensmul_data((self.metric, True, True)) 

1132 delete_tensmul_data((self.metric, True, False)) 

1133 delete_tensmul_data((self.metric, False, True)) 

1134 delete_tensmul_data((self.metric, False, False)) 

1135 

1136 # delete delta tensor data: 

1137 delta = self.get_kronecker_delta() 

1138 if delta in _tensor_data_substitution_dict: 

1139 del _tensor_data_substitution_dict[delta]

1141 

1142class TensorIndex(Basic): 

1143 """ 

1144 Represents an abstract tensor index. 

1145 

1146 Parameters 

1147 ========== 

1148 

1149 name : name of the index, or ``True`` if you want it to be automatically assigned 

1150 tensortype : ``TensorIndexType`` of the index 

1151 is_up : flag for contravariant index 

1152 

1153 Attributes 

1154 ========== 

1155 

1156 ``name`` 

1157 ``tensortype`` 

1158 ``is_up`` 

1159 

1160 Notes 

1161 ===== 

1162 

1163 Tensor indices are contracted with the Einstein summation convention. 

1164 

1165 An index can be in contravariant or in covariant form; in the latter 

1166 case it is represented prepending a ``-`` to the index name. 

1167 

1168 Dummy indices have a name with head given by ``tensortype._dummy_fmt`` 

1169 

1170 

1171 Examples 

1172 ======== 

1173 

1174 >>> from sympy.tensor.tensor import TensorIndexType, TensorIndex, TensorSymmetry, TensorType, get_symmetric_group_sgs 

1175 >>> Lorentz = TensorIndexType('Lorentz', dummy_fmt='L') 

1176 >>> i = TensorIndex('i', Lorentz); i 

1177 i 

1178 >>> sym1 = TensorSymmetry(*get_symmetric_group_sgs(1)) 

1179 >>> S1 = TensorType([Lorentz], sym1) 

1180 >>> A, B = S1('A,B') 

1181 >>> A(i)*B(-i) 

1182 A(L_0)*B(-L_0) 

1183 

1184 If you want the index name to be automatically assigned, just put ``True`` 

1185 in the ``name`` field, it will be generated using the reserved character 

1186 ``_`` in front of its name, in order to avoid conflicts with possible 

1187 existing indices: 

1188 

1189 >>> i0 = TensorIndex(True, Lorentz) 

1190 >>> i0 

1191 _i0 

1192 >>> i1 = TensorIndex(True, Lorentz) 

1193 >>> i1 

1194 _i1 

1195 >>> A(i0)*B(-i1) 

1196 A(_i0)*B(-_i1) 

1197 >>> A(i0)*B(-i0) 

1198 A(L_0)*B(-L_0) 

1199 """ 

1200 def __new__(cls, name, tensortype, is_up=True): 

1201 if isinstance(name, string_types): 

1202 name_symbol = Symbol(name) 

1203 elif isinstance(name, Symbol): 

1204 name_symbol = name 

1205 elif name is True: 

1206 name = "_i{0}".format(len(tensortype._autogenerated)) 

1207 name_symbol = Symbol(name) 

1208 tensortype._autogenerated.append(name_symbol) 

1209 else: 

1210 raise ValueError("invalid name") 

1211 

1212 is_up = sympify(is_up) 

1213 obj = Basic.__new__(cls, name_symbol, tensortype, is_up) 

1214 obj._name = str(name) 

1215 obj._tensor_index_type = tensortype 

1216 obj._is_up = is_up 

1217 return obj 

1218 

1219 @property 

1220 def name(self): 

1221 return self._name 

1222 

1223 @property 

1224 @deprecated(useinstead="tensor_index_type", issue=12857, deprecated_since_version="1.1") 

1225 def tensortype(self): 

1226 return self.tensor_index_type 

1227 

1228 @property 

1229 def tensor_index_type(self): 

1230 return self._tensor_index_type 

1231 

1232 @property 

1233 def is_up(self): 

1234 return self._is_up 

1235 

1236 def _print(self): 

1237 s = self._name 

1238 if not self._is_up: 

1239 s = '-%s' % s 

1240 return s 

1241 

1242 def __lt__(self, other): 

1243 return (self.tensor_index_type, self._name) < (other.tensor_index_type, other._name) 

1244 

1245 def __neg__(self): 

1246 t1 = TensorIndex(self.name, self.tensor_index_type, 

1247 (not self.is_up)) 

1248 return t1 

1249 

1250 

1251def tensor_indices(s, typ): 

1252 """ 

1253 Returns list of tensor indices given their names and their types 

1254 

1255 Parameters 

1256 ========== 

1257 

1258 s : string of comma separated names of indices 

1259 

1260 typ : ``TensorIndexType`` of the indices 

1261 

1262 Examples 

1263 ======== 

1264 

1265 >>> from sympy.tensor.tensor import TensorIndexType, tensor_indices 

1266 >>> Lorentz = TensorIndexType('Lorentz', dummy_fmt='L') 

1267 >>> a, b, c, d = tensor_indices('a,b,c,d', Lorentz) 

1268 """ 

1269 if isinstance(s, string_types): 

1270 a = [x.name for x in symbols(s, seq=True)] 

1271 else: 

1272 raise ValueError('expecting a string') 

1273 

1274 tilist = [TensorIndex(i, typ) for i in a] 

1275 if len(tilist) == 1: 

1276 return tilist[0] 

1277 return tilist 

1278 

1279 

1280class TensorSymmetry(Basic): 

1281 """ 

1282 Monoterm symmetry of a tensor 

1283 

1284 Parameters 

1285 ========== 

1286 

1287 bsgs : tuple ``(base, sgs)`` BSGS of the symmetry of the tensor 

1288 

1289 Attributes 

1290 ========== 

1291 

1292 ``base`` : base of the BSGS 

1293 ``generators`` : generators of the BSGS 

1294 ``rank`` : rank of the tensor 

1295 

1296 Notes 

1297 ===== 

1298 

1299 A tensor can have an arbitrary monoterm symmetry provided by its BSGS. 

1300 Multiterm symmetries, like the cyclic symmetry of the Riemann tensor, 

1301 are not covered. 

1302 

1303 See Also 

1304 ======== 

1305 

1306 sympy.combinatorics.tensor_can.get_symmetric_group_sgs 

1307 

1308 Examples 

1309 ======== 

1310 

1311 Define a symmetric tensor 

1312 

1313 >>> from sympy.tensor.tensor import TensorIndexType, TensorSymmetry, TensorType, get_symmetric_group_sgs 

1314 >>> Lorentz = TensorIndexType('Lorentz', dummy_fmt='L') 

1315 >>> sym2 = TensorSymmetry(get_symmetric_group_sgs(2)) 

1316 >>> S2 = TensorType([Lorentz]*2, sym2) 

1317 >>> V = S2('V') 

1318 """ 

1319 def __new__(cls, *args, **kw_args): 

1320 if len(args) == 1: 

1321 base, generators = args[0] 

1322 elif len(args) == 2: 

1323 base, generators = args 

1324 else: 

1325 raise TypeError("bsgs required, either two separate parameters or one tuple") 

1326 

1327 if not isinstance(base, Tuple): 

1328 base = Tuple(*base) 

1329 if not isinstance(generators, Tuple): 

1330 generators = Tuple(*generators) 

1331 obj = Basic.__new__(cls, base, generators, **kw_args) 

1332 return obj 

1333 

1334 @property 

1335 def base(self): 

1336 return self.args[0] 

1337 

1338 @property 

1339 def generators(self): 

1340 return self.args[1] 

1341 

1342 @property 

1343 def rank(self): 

1344 return self.args[1][0].size - 2 

1345 

1346 

1347def tensorsymmetry(*args): 

1348 """ 

1349 Return a ``TensorSymmetry`` object. 

1350 

1351 One can represent a tensor with any monoterm slot symmetry group 

1352 using a BSGS. 

1353 

1354 ``args`` can be a BSGS 

1355 ``args[0]`` base 

1356 ``args[1]`` sgs 

1357 

1358 Usually tensors are in (direct products of) representations 

1359 of the symmetric group; 

1360 ``args`` can be a list of lists representing the shapes of Young tableaux 

1361 

1362 Notes 

1363 ===== 

1364 

1365 For instance: 

1366 ``[[1]]`` vector 

1367 ``[[1]*n]`` symmetric tensor of rank ``n`` 

1368 ``[[n]]`` antisymmetric tensor of rank ``n`` 

1369 ``[[2, 2]]`` monoterm slot symmetry of the Riemann tensor 

1370 ``[[1],[1]]`` vector*vector 

1371 ``[[2],[1],[1]`` (antisymmetric tensor)*vector*vector 

1372 

1373 Notice that with the shape ``[2, 2]`` we associate only the monoterm 

1374 symmetries of the Riemann tensor; this is an abuse of notation, 

1375 since the shape ``[2, 2]`` corresponds usually to the irreducible 

1376 representation characterized by the monoterm symmetries and by the 

1377 cyclic symmetry. 

1378 

1379 Examples 

1380 ======== 

1381 

1382 Symmetric tensor using a Young tableau 

1383 

1384 >>> from sympy.tensor.tensor import TensorIndexType, TensorType, tensorsymmetry 

1385 >>> Lorentz = TensorIndexType('Lorentz', dummy_fmt='L') 

1386 >>> sym2 = tensorsymmetry([1, 1]) 

1387 >>> S2 = TensorType([Lorentz]*2, sym2) 

1388 >>> V = S2('V') 

1389 

1390 Symmetric tensor using a ``BSGS`` (base, strong generator set) 

1391 

1392 >>> from sympy.tensor.tensor import get_symmetric_group_sgs 

1393 >>> sym2 = tensorsymmetry(*get_symmetric_group_sgs(2)) 

1394 >>> S2 = TensorType([Lorentz]*2, sym2) 

1395 >>> V = S2('V') 

1396 """ 

1397 from sympy.combinatorics import Permutation 

1398 

1399 def tableau2bsgs(a): 

1400 if len(a) == 1: 

1401 # antisymmetric vector 

1402 n = a[0] 

1403 bsgs = get_symmetric_group_sgs(n, 1) 

1404 else: 

1405 if all(x == 1 for x in a): 

1406 # symmetric vector 

1407 n = len(a) 

1408 bsgs = get_symmetric_group_sgs(n) 

1409 elif a == [2, 2]: 

1410 bsgs = riemann_bsgs 

1411 else: 

1412 raise NotImplementedError 

1413 return bsgs 

1414 

1415 if not args: 

1416 return TensorSymmetry(Tuple(), Tuple(Permutation(1))) 

1417 

1418 if len(args) == 2 and isinstance(args[1][0], Permutation): 

1419 return TensorSymmetry(args) 

1420 base, sgs = tableau2bsgs(args[0]) 

1421 for a in args[1:]: 

1422 basex, sgsx = tableau2bsgs(a) 

1423 base, sgs = bsgs_direct_product(base, sgs, basex, sgsx) 

1424 return TensorSymmetry(Tuple(base, sgs)) 

1425 

1426 

1427class TensorType(Basic): 

1428 """ 

1429 Class of tensor types. 

1430 

1431 Parameters 

1432 ========== 

1433 

1434 index_types : list of ``TensorIndexType`` of the tensor indices 

1435 symmetry : ``TensorSymmetry`` of the tensor 

1436 

1437 Attributes 

1438 ========== 

1439 

1440 ``index_types`` 

1441 ``symmetry`` 

1442 ``types`` : list of ``TensorIndexType`` without repetitions 

1443 

1444 Examples 

1445 ======== 

1446 

1447 Define a symmetric tensor 

1448 

1449 >>> from sympy.tensor.tensor import TensorIndexType, tensorsymmetry, TensorType 

1450 >>> Lorentz = TensorIndexType('Lorentz', dummy_fmt='L') 

1451 >>> sym2 = tensorsymmetry([1, 1]) 

1452 >>> S2 = TensorType([Lorentz]*2, sym2) 

1453 >>> V = S2('V') 

1454 """ 

1455 is_commutative = False 

1456 

1457 def __new__(cls, index_types, symmetry, **kw_args): 

1458 assert symmetry.rank == len(index_types) 

1459 obj = Basic.__new__(cls, Tuple(*index_types), symmetry, **kw_args) 

1460 return obj 

1461 

1462 @property 

1463 def index_types(self): 

1464 return self.args[0] 

1465 

1466 @property 

1467 def symmetry(self): 

1468 return self.args[1] 

1469 

1470 @property 

1471 def types(self): 

1472 return sorted(set(self.index_types), key=lambda x: x.name) 

1473 

1474 def __str__(self): 

1475 return 'TensorType(%s)' % ([str(x) for x in self.index_types]) 

1476 

1477 def __call__(self, s, comm=0): 

1478 """ 

1479 Return a TensorHead object or a list of TensorHead objects. 

1480 

1481 ``s`` name or string of names 

1482 

1483 ``comm``: commutation group number 

1484 see ``_TensorManager.set_comm`` 

1485 

1486 Examples 

1487 ======== 

1488 

1489 Define symmetric tensors ``V``, ``W`` and ``G``, respectively 

1490 commuting, anticommuting and with no commutation symmetry 

1491 

1492 >>> from sympy.tensor.tensor import TensorIndexType, tensor_indices, tensorsymmetry, TensorType, canon_bp 

1493 >>> Lorentz = TensorIndexType('Lorentz', dummy_fmt='L') 

1494 >>> a, b = tensor_indices('a,b', Lorentz) 

1495 >>> sym2 = tensorsymmetry([1]*2) 

1496 >>> S2 = TensorType([Lorentz]*2, sym2) 

1497 >>> V = S2('V') 

1498 >>> W = S2('W', 1) 

1499 >>> G = S2('G', 2) 

1500 >>> canon_bp(V(a, b)*V(-b, -a)) 

1501 V(L_0, L_1)*V(-L_0, -L_1) 

1502 >>> canon_bp(W(a, b)*W(-b, -a)) 

1503 0 

1504 """ 

1505 if isinstance(s, string_types): 

1506 names = [x.name for x in symbols(s, seq=True)] 

1507 else: 

1508 raise ValueError('expecting a string') 

1509 if len(names) == 1: 

1510 return TensorHead(names[0], self, comm) 

1511 else: 

1512 return [TensorHead(name, self, comm) for name in names] 

1513 

1514 

1515def tensorhead(name, typ, sym=None, comm=0): 

1516 """ 

1517 Function generating tensorhead(s). 

1518 

1519 Parameters 

1520 ========== 

1521 

1522 name : name or sequence of names (as in ``symbol``) 

1523 

1524 typ : index types 

1525 

1526 sym : same as ``*args`` in ``tensorsymmetry`` 

1527 

1528 comm : commutation group number 

1529 see ``_TensorManager.set_comm`` 

1530 

1531 

1532 Examples 

1533 ======== 

1534 

1535 >>> from sympy.tensor.tensor import TensorIndexType, tensor_indices, tensorhead 

1536 >>> Lorentz = TensorIndexType('Lorentz', dummy_fmt='L') 

1537 >>> a, b = tensor_indices('a,b', Lorentz) 

1538 >>> A = tensorhead('A', [Lorentz]*2, [[1]*2]) 

1539 >>> A(a, -b) 

1540 A(a, -b) 

1541 

1542 If no symmetry parameter is provided, assume there are not index 

1543 symmetries: 

1544 

1545 >>> B = tensorhead('B', [Lorentz, Lorentz]) 

1546 >>> B(a, -b) 

1547 B(a, -b) 

1548 

1549 """ 

1550 if sym is None: 

1551 sym = [[1] for i in range(len(typ))] 

1552 sym = tensorsymmetry(*sym) 

1553 S = TensorType(typ, sym) 

1554 th = S(name, comm) 

1555 return th 

1556 

1557 

1558class TensorHead(Basic): 

1559 r""" 

1560 Tensor head of the tensor 

1561 

1562 Parameters 

1563 ========== 

1564 

1565 name : name of the tensor 

1566 

1567 typ : list of TensorIndexType 

1568 

1569 comm : commutation group number 

1570 

1571 Attributes 

1572 ========== 

1573 

1574 ``name`` 

1575 ``index_types`` 

1576 ``rank`` 

1577 ``types`` : equal to ``typ.types`` 

1578 ``symmetry`` : equal to ``typ.symmetry`` 

1579 ``comm`` : commutation group 

1580 

1581 Notes 

1582 ===== 

1583 

1584 A ``TensorHead`` belongs to a commutation group, defined by a 

1585 symbol on number ``comm`` (see ``_TensorManager.set_comm``); 

1586 tensors in a commutation group have the same commutation properties; 

1587 by default ``comm`` is ``0``, the group of the commuting tensors. 

1588 

1589 Examples 

1590 ======== 

1591 

1592 >>> from sympy.tensor.tensor import TensorIndexType, tensorhead, TensorType 

1593 >>> Lorentz = TensorIndexType('Lorentz', dummy_fmt='L') 

1594 >>> A = tensorhead('A', [Lorentz, Lorentz], [[1],[1]]) 

1595 

1596 Examples with ndarray values, the components data assigned to the 

1597 ``TensorHead`` object are assumed to be in a fully-contravariant 

1598 representation. In case it is necessary to assign components data which 

1599 represents the values of a non-fully covariant tensor, see the other 

1600 examples. 

1601 

1602 >>> from sympy.tensor.tensor import tensor_indices, tensorhead 

1603 >>> from sympy import diag 

1604 >>> i0, i1 = tensor_indices('i0:2', Lorentz) 

1605 

1606 Specify a replacement dictionary to keep track of the arrays to use for 

1607 replacements in the tensorial expression. The ``TensorIndexType`` is 

1608 associated to the metric used for contractions (in fully covariant form): 

1609 

1610 >>> repl = {Lorentz: diag(1, -1, -1, -1)} 

1611 

1612 Let's see some examples of working with components with the electromagnetic 

1613 tensor: 

1614 

1615 >>> from sympy import symbols 

1616 >>> Ex, Ey, Ez, Bx, By, Bz = symbols('E_x E_y E_z B_x B_y B_z') 

1617 >>> c = symbols('c', positive=True) 

1618 

1619 Let's define `F`, an antisymmetric tensor, we have to assign an 

1620 antisymmetric matrix to it, because `[[2]]` stands for the Young tableau 

1621 representation of an antisymmetric set of two elements: 

1622 

1623 >>> F = tensorhead('F', [Lorentz, Lorentz], [[2]]) 

1624 

1625 Let's update the dictionary to contain the matrix to use in the 

1626 replacements: 

1627 

1628 >>> repl.update({F(-i0, -i1): [ 

1629 ... [0, Ex/c, Ey/c, Ez/c], 

1630 ... [-Ex/c, 0, -Bz, By], 

1631 ... [-Ey/c, Bz, 0, -Bx], 

1632 ... [-Ez/c, -By, Bx, 0]]}) 

1633 

1634 Now it is possible to retrieve the contravariant form of the Electromagnetic 

1635 tensor: 

1636 

1637 >>> F(i0, i1).replace_with_arrays(repl, [i0, i1]) 

1638 [[0, -E_x/c, -E_y/c, -E_z/c], [E_x/c, 0, -B_z, B_y], [E_y/c, B_z, 0, -B_x], [E_z/c, -B_y, B_x, 0]] 

1639 

1640 and the mixed contravariant-covariant form: 

1641 

1642 >>> F(i0, -i1).replace_with_arrays(repl, [i0, -i1]) 

1643 [[0, E_x/c, E_y/c, E_z/c], [E_x/c, 0, B_z, -B_y], [E_y/c, -B_z, 0, B_x], [E_z/c, B_y, -B_x, 0]] 

1644 

1645 Energy-momentum of a particle may be represented as: 

1646 

1647 >>> from sympy import symbols 

1648 >>> P = tensorhead('P', [Lorentz], [[1]]) 

1649 >>> E, px, py, pz = symbols('E p_x p_y p_z', positive=True) 

1650 >>> repl.update({P(i0): [E, px, py, pz]}) 

1651 

1652 The contravariant and covariant components are, respectively: 

1653 

1654 >>> P(i0).replace_with_arrays(repl, [i0]) 

1655 [E, p_x, p_y, p_z] 

1656 >>> P(-i0).replace_with_arrays(repl, [-i0]) 

1657 [E, -p_x, -p_y, -p_z] 

1658 

1659 The contraction of a 1-index tensor by itself: 

1660 

1661 >>> expr = P(i0)*P(-i0) 

1662 >>> expr.replace_with_arrays(repl, []) 

1663 E**2 - p_x**2 - p_y**2 - p_z**2 

1664 """ 

1665 is_commutative = False 

1666 

1667 def __new__(cls, name, typ, comm=0, **kw_args): 

1668 if isinstance(name, string_types): 

1669 name_symbol = Symbol(name) 

1670 elif isinstance(name, Symbol): 

1671 name_symbol = name 

1672 else: 

1673 raise ValueError("invalid name") 

1674 

1675 comm2i = TensorManager.comm_symbols2i(comm) 

1676 

1677 obj = Basic.__new__(cls, name_symbol, typ, **kw_args) 

1678 

1679 obj._name = obj.args[0].name 

1680 obj._rank = len(obj.index_types) 

1681 obj._symmetry = typ.symmetry 

1682 obj._comm = comm2i 

1683 return obj 

1684 

1685 @property 

1686 def name(self): 

1687 return self._name 

1688 

1689 @property 

1690 def rank(self): 

1691 return self._rank 

1692 

1693 @property 

1694 def symmetry(self): 

1695 return self._symmetry 

1696 

1697 @property 

1698 def typ(self): 

1699 return self.args[1] 

1700 

1701 @property 

1702 def comm(self): 

1703 return self._comm 

1704 

1705 @property 

1706 def types(self): 

1707 return self.args[1].types[:] 

1708 

1709 @property 

1710 def index_types(self): 

1711 return self.args[1].index_types[:] 

1712 

1713 def __lt__(self, other): 

1714 return (self.name, self.index_types) < (other.name, other.index_types) 

1715 

1716 def commutes_with(self, other): 

1717 """ 

1718 Returns ``0`` if ``self`` and ``other`` commute, ``1`` if they anticommute. 

1719 

1720 Returns ``None`` if ``self`` and ``other`` neither commute nor anticommute. 

1721 """ 

1722 r = TensorManager.get_comm(self._comm, other._comm) 

1723 return r 

1724 

1725 def _print(self): 

1726 return '%s(%s)' %(self.name, ','.join([str(x) for x in self.index_types])) 

1727 

1728 def __call__(self, *indices, **kw_args): 

1729 """ 

1730 Returns a tensor with indices. 

1731 

1732 There is a special behavior in case of indices denoted by ``True``, 

1733 they are considered auto-matrix indices, their slots are automatically 

1734 filled, and confer to the tensor the behavior of a matrix or vector 

1735 upon multiplication with another tensor containing auto-matrix indices 

1736 of the same ``TensorIndexType``. This means indices get summed over the 

1737 same way as in matrix multiplication. For matrix behavior, define two 

1738 auto-matrix indices, for vector behavior define just one. 

1739 

1740 Examples 

1741 ======== 

1742 

1743 >>> from sympy.tensor.tensor import TensorIndexType, tensor_indices, tensorhead 

1744 >>> Lorentz = TensorIndexType('Lorentz', dummy_fmt='L') 

1745 >>> a, b = tensor_indices('a,b', Lorentz) 

1746 >>> A = tensorhead('A', [Lorentz]*2, [[1]*2]) 

1747 >>> t = A(a, -b) 

1748 >>> t 

1749 A(a, -b) 

1750 

1751 """ 

1752 tensor = Tensor(self, indices, **kw_args) 

1753 return tensor.doit() 

1754 

1755 def __pow__(self, other): 

1756 with warnings.catch_warnings(): 

1757 warnings.filterwarnings("ignore", category=SymPyDeprecationWarning) 

1758 if self.data is None: 

1759 raise ValueError("No power on abstract tensors.") 

1760 deprecate_data() 

1761 from .array import tensorproduct, tensorcontraction 

1762 metrics = [_.data for _ in self.args[1].args[0]] 

1763 

1764 marray = self.data 

1765 marraydim = marray.rank() 

1766 for metric in metrics: 

1767 marray = tensorproduct(marray, metric, marray) 

1768 marray = tensorcontraction(marray, (0, marraydim), (marraydim+1, marraydim+2)) 

1769 

1770 return marray ** (Rational(1, 2) * other) 

1771 

1772 @property 

1773 def data(self): 

1774 deprecate_data() 

1775 return _tensor_data_substitution_dict[self] 

1776 

1777 @data.setter 

1778 def data(self, data): 

1779 deprecate_data() 

1780 _tensor_data_substitution_dict[self] = data 

1781 

1782 @data.deleter 

1783 def data(self): 

1784 deprecate_data() 

1785 if self in _tensor_data_substitution_dict: 

1786 del _tensor_data_substitution_dict[self] 

1787 

1788 def __iter__(self): 

1789 deprecate_data() 

1790 return self.data.__iter__() 

1791 

1792 def _components_data_full_destroy(self): 

1793 """ 

1794 EXPERIMENTAL: do not rely on this API method. 

1795 

1796 Destroy components data associated to the ``TensorHead`` object, this 

1797 checks for attached components data, and destroys components data too. 

1798 """ 

1799 # do not garbage collect Kronecker tensor (it should be done by 

1800 # ``TensorIndexType`` garbage collection) 

1801 if self.name == "KD": 

1802 return 

1803 

1804 # the data attached to a tensor must be deleted only by the TensorHead 

1805 # destructor. If the TensorHead is deleted, it means that there are no 

1806 # more instances of that tensor anywhere. 

1807 if self in _tensor_data_substitution_dict: 

1808 del _tensor_data_substitution_dict[self] 

1809 

1810 

1811def _get_argtree_pos(expr, pos): 

1812 for p in pos: 

1813 expr = expr.args[p] 

1814 return expr 

1815 

1816 

1817class TensExpr(Expr): 

1818 """ 

1819 Abstract base class for tensor expressions 

1820 

1821 Notes 

1822 ===== 

1823 

1824 A tensor expression is an expression formed by tensors; 

1825 currently the sums of tensors are distributed. 

1826 

1827 A ``TensExpr`` can be a ``TensAdd`` or a ``TensMul``. 

1828 

1829 ``TensAdd`` objects are put in canonical form using the Butler-Portugal 

1830 algorithm for canonicalization under monoterm symmetries. 

1831 

1832 ``TensMul`` objects are formed by products of component tensors, 

1833 and include a coefficient, which is a SymPy expression. 

1834 

1835 

1836 In the internal representation contracted indices are represented 

1837 by ``(ipos1, ipos2, icomp1, icomp2)``, where ``icomp1`` is the position 

1838 of the component tensor with contravariant index, ``ipos1`` is the 

1839 slot which the index occupies in that component tensor. 

1840 

1841 Contracted indices are therefore nameless in the internal representation. 

1842 """ 

1843 

1844 _op_priority = 12.0 

1845 is_commutative = False 

1846 

1847 def __neg__(self): 

1848 return self*S.NegativeOne 

1849 

1850 def __abs__(self): 

1851 raise NotImplementedError 

1852 

1853 def __add__(self, other): 

1854 return TensAdd(self, other).doit() 

1855 

1856 def __radd__(self, other): 

1857 return TensAdd(other, self).doit() 

1858 

1859 def __sub__(self, other): 

1860 return TensAdd(self, -other).doit() 

1861 

1862 def __rsub__(self, other): 

1863 return TensAdd(other, -self).doit() 

1864 

1865 def __mul__(self, other): 

1866 """ 

1867 Multiply two tensors using Einstein summation convention. 

1868 

1869 If the two tensors have an index in common, one contravariant 

1870 and the other covariant, in their product the indices are summed 

1871 

1872 Examples 

1873 ======== 

1874 

1875 >>> from sympy.tensor.tensor import TensorIndexType, tensor_indices, tensorhead 

1876 >>> Lorentz = TensorIndexType('Lorentz', dummy_fmt='L') 

1877 >>> m0, m1, m2 = tensor_indices('m0,m1,m2', Lorentz) 

1878 >>> g = Lorentz.metric 

1879 >>> p, q = tensorhead('p,q', [Lorentz], [[1]]) 

1880 >>> t1 = p(m0) 

1881 >>> t2 = q(-m0) 

1882 >>> t1*t2 

1883 p(L_0)*q(-L_0) 

1884 """ 

1885 return TensMul(self, other).doit() 

1886 

1887 def __rmul__(self, other): 

1888 return TensMul(other, self).doit() 

1889 

1890 def __div__(self, other): 

1891 other = _sympify(other) 

1892 if isinstance(other, TensExpr): 

1893 raise ValueError('cannot divide by a tensor') 

1894 return TensMul(self, S.One/other).doit() 

1895 

1896 def __rdiv__(self, other): 

1897 raise ValueError('cannot divide by a tensor') 

1898 

1899 def __pow__(self, other): 

1900 with warnings.catch_warnings(): 

1901 warnings.filterwarnings("ignore", category=SymPyDeprecationWarning) 

1902 if self.data is None: 

1903 raise ValueError("No power without ndarray data.") 

1904 deprecate_data() 

1905 from .array import tensorproduct, tensorcontraction 

1906 free = self.free 

1907 marray = self.data 

1908 mdim = marray.rank() 

1909 for metric in free: 

1910 marray = tensorcontraction( 

1911 tensorproduct( 

1912 marray, 

1913 metric[0].tensor_index_type.data, 

1914 marray), 

1915 (0, mdim), (mdim+1, mdim+2) 

1916 ) 

1917 return marray ** (Rational(1, 2) * other) 

1918 

1919 def __rpow__(self, other): 

1920 raise NotImplementedError 

1921 

1922 __truediv__ = __div__ 

1923 __rtruediv__ = __rdiv__ 

1924 

1925 def fun_eval(self, *index_tuples): 

1926 """ 

1927 Return a tensor with free indices substituted according to ``index_tuples`` 

1928 

1929 ``index_types`` list of tuples ``(old_index, new_index)`` 

1930 

1931 Examples 

1932 ======== 

1933 

1934 >>> from sympy.tensor.tensor import TensorIndexType, tensor_indices, tensorhead 

1935 >>> Lorentz = TensorIndexType('Lorentz', dummy_fmt='L') 

1936 >>> i, j, k, l = tensor_indices('i,j,k,l', Lorentz) 

1937 >>> A, B = tensorhead('A,B', [Lorentz]*2, [[1]*2]) 

1938 >>> t = A(i, k)*B(-k, -j); t 

1939 A(i, L_0)*B(-L_0, -j) 

1940 >>> t.fun_eval((i, k),(-j, l)) 

1941 A(k, L_0)*B(-L_0, l) 

1942 """ 

1943 expr = self.xreplace(dict(index_tuples)) 

1944 expr = expr.replace(lambda x: isinstance(x, Tensor), lambda x: x.args[0](*x.args[1])) 

1945 # For some reason, `TensMul` gets replaced by `Mul`, correct it: 

1946 expr = expr.replace(lambda x: isinstance(x, (Mul, TensMul)), lambda x: TensMul(*x.args).doit()) 

1947 return expr 

1948 

1949 def get_matrix(self): 

1950 """ 

1951 DEPRECATED: do not use. 

1952 

1953 Returns ndarray components data as a matrix, if components data are 

1954 available and ndarray dimension does not exceed 2. 

1955 """ 

1956 from sympy import Matrix 

1957 deprecate_data() 

1958 if 0 < self.rank <= 2: 

1959 rows = self.data.shape[0] 

1960 columns = self.data.shape[1] if self.rank == 2 else 1 

1961 if self.rank == 2: 

1962 mat_list = [] * rows 

1963 for i in range(rows): 

1964 mat_list.append([]) 

1965 for j in range(columns): 

1966 mat_list[i].append(self[i, j]) 

1967 else: 

1968 mat_list = [None] * rows 

1969 for i in range(rows): 

1970 mat_list[i] = self[i] 

1971 return Matrix(mat_list) 

1972 else: 

1973 raise NotImplementedError( 

1974 "missing multidimensional reduction to matrix.") 

1975 

1976 @staticmethod 

1977 def _get_indices_permutation(indices1, indices2): 

1978 return [indices1.index(i) for i in indices2] 

1979 

1980 def expand(self, **hints): 

1981 return _expand(self, **hints).doit() 

1982 

1983 def _expand(self, **kwargs): 

1984 return self

1988 for arg in self.args: 

1989 if isinstance(arg, TensExpr): 

1990 indset.update(arg._get_free_indices_set()) 

1991 return indset
